quoteFirst: First I found a ring—a wedding ring—with ‘From R.’ and a date inside it. Then I learnt that Ralph Paton had been seen coming up the path which led to the summer-house at
quoteLast: , and I also heard of a certain conversation which had taken place in the wood near the village that very afternoon—a conversation between Ralph Paton and some unknown girl. So I had my facts succeeding each other in a neat and orderly manner.
title: The murder of Roger Ackroyd
author: Christie, Agatha, 1890-1976

quoteFirst: "You will carry, each, a crash towel, a sponge, and soap," she announced to Katy, "and will be in the entry, at the foot of the stairs, at
quoteLast: precisely.  Failures in punctuality will be punished by a mark."  Miss Jane always delivered her words like a machine, and closed her mouth with a snap at the end of the sentence.

quoteFirst: Sands and I went ashore and took tea at Mr. Samuel B----'s. We spent a very pleasant time. Mr. Skinner, D.D., was present. At 8 p.m. we got under weigh, and proceeded to Chowan river, and came to anchor at
quoteLast: for the night. The weather is delightful. Wednesday, January 18, at 5 a.m. we got under weigh, and proceeded to Holly's Landing, where we anchored at 7 a.m.
title: Reminiscences of Two Years in the United States Navy

quoteFirst: The Scouts would have preferred to camp, but Walz kept insisting that they push on to Elks Creek. Actually, it was
quoteLast: when the car finally pulled into that little mountainside hamlet. There was no suitable camp site, and for once the wearied Scouts had no enthusiasm about finding one.

quoteLast: , October 14, 1912, by the Chief of Police, John T. Janssen, we find that he objected to telling his name, but did so when it was insisted upon.

quoteFirst: Instead, the wearing discomforts of the journey are likely to retain chief hold upon the memory. Can I ever forget how we waited seven hours for a train due at
quoteLast: at a station that possessed no forms to sit upon, so that some of the men lay at full length and slept on the asphalt platform? And is there not a corner of my memory for the crawling fusty leave-train that had bare planks nailed across the door spaces of some of the "officers'" compartments; a train so packed that we three officers took turns on the one spare seat in an "other ranks" carriage? And then about 8 A.M. we landed at a well-known "all-change" siding, a spot of such vivid recollections that some one had pencilled in the ablution-house, "If the Huns ever take ---- Camp and have to
title: Pushed and the Return Push
